dt: {bc}deficient in color or intensity of color {bc}{sx|pallid||}
{bc}light in color especially relative to others of its kind

dt.t: a {wi}pale{/wi} sun shining through the fog

et: Middle English {it}pale, paal, palle,{/it} borrowed from Anglo-French {it}pale, palle, paille{/it} (also continental Old French), borrowed (with loss of unstressed {it}-id-{/it}) from Latin {it}pallidus{/it} "pale, colorless," formed with the adjective suffix {it}-idus{/it} from the same base as {it}pallēre{/it} "to be pale or bloodless, have a pale color," {it}pallor{/it} "paleness of complexion, loss of color" {ma}{mat|fallow:1|}{/ma}
shortdef: deficient in color or intensity of color : pallid
light in color especially relative to others of its kind

et: Middle English {it}palen,{/it} borrowed from Anglo-French palir (continental Old French {it}palir, paloïr{/it}), going back (with conjugation change) to Latin {it}pallēscere{/it} "to grow pale, turn a pale color," inchoative derivative of {it}pallēre{/it} "to be pale or bloodless, have a pale color" {ma}{mat|fallow:1|}{/ma}

dt: {bc}an area or the limits within which one is privileged or protected (as from censure)

dt.t: The cattle were led into the {wi}pale{/wi}.

dt: {bc}a territory or district within certain bounds or under a particular jurisdiction

dt.t: British culture survived even within the Roman {wi}pale{/wi}.

dt: {bc}a perpendicular stripe on a heraldic shield

et: Middle English, from Anglo-French {it}pel, pal{/it} stake, from Latin {it}palus{/it} {ma}{mat|pole|}{/ma}
shortdef: an area or the limits within which one is privileged or protected (as from censure)
a space or field having bounds : enclosure
a territory or district within certain bounds or under a particular jurisdiction

dt: {bc}involving or dealing with ancient forms or conditions

et: borrowed from New Latin {it}palaeo-,{/it} borrowed from Greek {it}palaio-,{/it} combining form from {it}palaiós{/it} "old, of long standing, ancient," adjective derivative of {it}pálai{/it} "long since, in the past," of uncertain origin

Greek {it}pálai{/it} was formerly compared with {it}têle{/it} "far off, in the distance," both being referred to an Indo-European base {it}*k{sup}w{/sup}el-,{/it} whence also Sanskrit {it}caramáḥ{/it} "outermost, last." However, if Mycenaean Greek {it}pa-ra-jo-{/it} is correctly glossed as "old," the etymon would not have begun with a labiovelar and the comparison falls into serious difficulty. See John Chadwick, "The Etymology of Greek πάλαι," {it}Glotta,{/it} Band 54, Heft 1 (1976), pp. 68-71; Chadwick suggests that if the original meaning of {it}pálai{/it} was "in the recent past, before now," the word could be connected with {it}pélas{/it} "near," {it}plēsíon{/it} "nearby, neighboring."
shortdef: involving or dealing with ancient forms or conditions

dt: {bc}a usually medium-colored, very dry {d_link|ale|ale} with a strong flavor of {d_link|hops|hop:3} {dx}see also {dxt|india pale ale||}{/dx}

shortdef: a usually medium-colored, very dry ale with a strong flavor of hops

dt: {bc}to seem less important, good, serious, etc., when compared with something else

dt.t: Once you've tasted the local apples, all others {it}pale by comparison{/it}.

shortdef: to seem less important, good, serious, etc., when compared with something else

dt.t: The remake of the movie was a {it}pale imitation{/it} of the original.

dt: {bc}to seem less important, good, serious, etc., when compared with (something else)

dt.t: The afternoon meal {it}paled in comparison to/with{/it} the feast they had later.
Last year's losses {it}pale by comparison with{/it} this year's.

shortdef: to seem less important, good, serious, etc., when compared with (something else)
